generateSmallPrimes

public static java.util.ArrayList<java.math.BigInteger> generateSmallPrimes(int primeBound,
                                                                            int startingPrime)
This method generates small prime numbers up to a specified bounds using the Sieve of Eratosthenes algorithm.

Parameters:
primeBound - The upper bound for the primes to be generated
startingPrime - The first prime in the list of primes that is returned
Returns:
List of primes up to the specified bound. Each prime is a APInteger object.

isMillerRabinWitness

                                           java.math.BigInteger N)
Tests if A is a Miller-Rabin witness for N

Parameters:
A - Number which is supposed to be the witness
N - Number to be tested against
Returns:
true if A is Miller-Rabin witness for N, false otherwise

setForceSingleThread

genSafePrime

public final java.math.BigInteger genSafePrime(int bitLength,
                                               int primeCertainty)
The main method to compute a random safe prime of the specified bit length. IMPORTANT: The computed prime will have two first bits and the last bit set to 1 !! i.e. > (2^(bitLength-1)+2^(bitLength-2)+1). This is done to be sure that if two primes of bitLength n are multiplied, the result will have the bitLength of 2*n exactly. This implementation uses the algorithm proposed by Ronald Cramer and Victor Shoup in "Signature Schemes Based on the strong RSA Assumption" May 9, 2000.

Parameters:
bitLength - The bit length of the safe prime to be computed.
primeCertainty - The error probability that the computed number is not prime is (2^(-primeCertainty))
Returns:
A prime number p which is considered to be safe with the prime certainty specified above. It has the property of p = 2p'+ 1 with both, p and p' being prime.
